member.name: T:SDG.NetPak.NetEnumAttribute
member.summary: Indicates net reader/writer implementation should be generated.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.UnityNetPakWriterEx.WriteQuaternion(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,UnityEngine.Quaternion,System.Int32)
member.summary: Uses "smallest three" optimization described by Glenn Fiedler: https://gafferongames.com/post/snapshot_compression/ Quoting here in case the link moves: "Since we know the quaternion represents a rotation its length must be 1, so x^2+y^2+z^2+w^2 = 1. We can use this identity to drop one component and reconstruct it on the other side. For example, if you send x,y,z you can reconstruct w = sqrt(1 - x^2 - y^2 - z^2). You might think you need to send a sign bit for w in case it is negative, but you don’t, because you can make w always positive by negating the entire quaternion if w is negative (in quaternion space (x,y,z,w) and (-x,-y,-z,-w) represent the same rotation.) Don’t always drop the same component due to numerical precision issues. Instead, find the component with the largest absolute value and encode its index using two bits [0, 3] (0=x, 1=y, 2=z, 3=w), then send the index of the largest component and the smallest three components over the network (hence the name). On the other side use the index of the largest bit to know which component you have to reconstruct from the other three."

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.UnityNetPakWriterEx.WriteNormalVector3(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Int32)
member.summary: Similar to the quaternion optimization, but needs a sign bit for the largest value.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.UnityNetPakWriterEx.WriteClampedVector3(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Default intBitCount of 13 allows a range of [-4096, +4096).

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.UnityNetPakWriterEx.WriteColor32RGB(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,UnityEngine.Color32)
member.summary: Write 8-bit per channel color excluding alpha.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.UnityNetPakWriterEx.WriteColor32RGBA(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,UnityEngine.Color32)
member.summary: Write 8-bit per channel color including alpha.

member.name: T:SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter
member.summary: Packs bits into a 32-bit buffer value, and from there into a byte array. GafferOnGames recommends this approach rather than "farting across a buffer at byte level like it's 1985".

member.name: T:SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter.EErrorFlags
member.summary: Lightweight error when exceptions are disabled. Bitwise OR to prevent different errors from clobbering each other.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.UnityNetPakReaderEx.ReadQuaternion(SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader,UnityEngine.Quaternion@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Uses "smallest three" optimization described by Glenn Fiedler: https://gafferongames.com/post/snapshot_compression/ Quoting here in case the link moves: "Since we know the quaternion represents a rotation its length must be 1, so x^2+y^2+z^2+w^2 = 1. We can use this identity to drop one component and reconstruct it on the other side. For example, if you send x,y,z you can reconstruct w = sqrt(1 - x^2 - y^2 - z^2). You might think you need to send a sign bit for w in case it is negative, but you don’t, because you can make w always positive by negating the entire quaternion if w is negative (in quaternion space (x,y,z,w) and (-x,-y,-z,-w) represent the same rotation.) Don’t always drop the same component due to numerical precision issues. Instead, find the component with the largest absolute value and encode its index using two bits [0, 3] (0=x, 1=y, 2=z, 3=w), then send the index of the largest component and the smallest three components over the network (hence the name). On the other side use the index of the largest bit to know which component you have to reconstruct from the other three."

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.UnityNetPakReaderEx.ReadNormalVector3(SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader,UnityEngine.Vector3@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Similar to the quaternion optimization, but needs a sign bit for the largest value.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.UnityNetPakReaderEx.ReadClampedVector3(SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader,UnityEngine.Vector3@,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Default intBitCount of 13 allows a range of [-4096, +4096).

member.summary: Read 8-bit per channel color excluding alpha.

member.summary: Read 8-bit per channel color excluding alpha.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakWriterEx.WriteSignedInt(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: For example bitCount of 7 allows range [-64, +64).

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakWriterEx.WriteClampedFloat(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Values outside the range are clamped into range. For example intBitCount of 7 allows range [-64, +64).

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakWriterEx.WriteUnsignedNormalizedFloat(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Encode a float in the range [0.0, 1.0]. Endpoints are encoded exactly, but not the midpoint (0.5).

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakWriterEx.WriteSignedNormalizedFloat(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Encode a float in the range [-1.0, +1.0]. Endpoints and midpoint (0.0) are encoded exactly.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakWriterEx.WriteRadians(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Encode radians wrapped into the range [0, TWO_PI).

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakWriterEx.WriteDegrees(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Encode degrees wrapped into the range [0, 360).

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakWriterEx.WriteEnum``1(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,``0)
member.summary: Placeholder allowing user assembly to compile before specialized implementation is generated.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakWriterEx.WriteStateArray(SDG.NetPak.NetPakWriter,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Ideally should not be used by new code.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakReaderEx.ReadSignedInt(SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: For example bitCount of 7 allows range [-64, +64).

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakReaderEx.ReadClampedFloat(SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single@)
member.summary: Values outside the range are clamped into range. For example intBitCount of 7 allows range [-64, +64).

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakReaderEx.ReadUnsignedNormalizedFloat(SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader,System.Int32,System.Single@)
member.summary: Decode a float in the range [0.0, 1.0]. Endpoints are encoded exactly, but not the midpoint (0.5).

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakReaderEx.ReadSignedNormalizedFloat(SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader,System.Int32,System.Single@)
member.summary: Decode a float in the range [-1.0, +1.0]. Endpoints and midpoint (0.0) are encoded exactly.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakReaderEx.ReadEnum``1(SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader,``0@)
member.summary: Placeholder allowing user assembly to compile before specialized implementation is generated.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.SystemNetPakReaderEx.ReadStateArray(SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader,System.Byte[]@)
member.summary: Ideally should not be used by new code.

member.name: T:SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader
member.summary: Unpacks bits from a byte array into a 32-bit buffer value. GafferOnGames recommends this approach rather than "farting across a buffer at byte level like it's 1985".

member.name: T:SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader.EErrorFlags
member.summary: Lightweight error when exceptions are disabled. Bitwise OR to prevent different errors from clobbering each other.

member.name: F:SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader.EErrorFlags.SourceBufferOverflow
member.summary: Call to ReadBits or ReadBytes would have overflowed our buffer.

member.name: F:SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader.EErrorFlags.DestinationBufferOverflow
member.summary: Buffer passed into ReadBytes would have overflowed.

member.name: F:SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader.EErrorFlags.AlignmentPadding
member.summary: AlignToByte bits should be zero.

member.name: F:SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader.EErrorFlags.SaveStateBufferOverflow
member.summary: Buffer passed into SaveState would have overflowed.

member.name: P:SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader.ReachedEndOfSegment
member.summary: Imprecise because sent byte length is rounded up from bit length, but should help find particularly egregious reading errors.

member.name: P:SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader.RemainingSegmentLength
member.summary: Number of bytes until end of segment is reached.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader.SaveState(System.UInt32@,System.Int32@,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Save remaining data to resume reading later. Used by net invokables to defer invocation.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader.ResetErrors
member.summary: Used by invocation messages to show more error context rather than the default.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader.SetBufferSegmentCopy(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Used by NetInvokable loopback to copy buffer from writer to reader.

member.name: M:SDG.NetPak.NetPakReader.ReadBytesPtr(System.Int32,System.Byte[]@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Assumes length is greater than zero! Moves reader forward according to length.

member.name: F:SDG.NetPak.NetPakConst.INV_SQRT_OF_TWO
member.summary: Uses "smallest three" optimization described by Glenn Fiedler: https://gafferongames.com/post/snapshot_compression/ Quoting here in case the link moves: "If v is the absolute value of the largest quaternion component, the next largest possible component value occurs when two components have the same absolute value and the other two components are zero. The length of that quaternion (v,v,0,0) is 1, therefore v^2 + v^2 = 1, 2v^2 = 1, v = 1/sqrt(2). This means you can encode the smallest three components in [-0.707107,+0.707107] instead of [-1,+1] giving you more precision with the same number of bits."

member.name: F:SDG.NetPak.NetPakConst.MAX_STRING_BYTE_COUNT_BITS
member.summary: Maximum number of bits to read/write for string byte count without overflowing the string buffer.

member.name: F:SDG.NetPak.NetPakConst.MAX_STRING_BYTE_COUNT
member.summary: Maximum number of UTF8 bytes for string. Before the "null or empty" flag was added the length had to be able to represent 0, but now the receiver can infer that the byte count is at least 1.

member.name: F:SDG.NetPak.NetPakConst.stringEncoding
member.summary: encoderShouldEmitUTF8Identifier enables byte order mark (BOM) which is unnecessary for UTF8. throwOnInvalidBytes allows reader to discard bad string packets.
